title: Writing Your First ImageJ Macro
text:
A macro is an automated input sequence that imitates keystrokes or mouse actions. Instead of clicking around manually, you can write a macro to:

Repeat tasks on many images. How many times do you click split channels > max projection over and over‚Ä¶
Streamline analysis and saving of results
Automate/Semi-automate analysis
Build reproducible analysis pipelines

In FIJI, you write macros in a special scripting language called the ijm language. You do not need to know how to ‚Äòcode‚Äô to generate a macro in FIJI. However, learning some basics of macro syntax and workflow can improve the capacity to modify, debug (errors happen all too often), and fully automate analysis routines.






Note



The IJM language was actually the first coding language I learnt. It is a great language to learn for beginner coders or the experienced!

section: ‚úÖ Tips Before Writing Your First Macro
text:
‚úÖ Tips Before Writing Your First Macro

Coding is unforgiving. It needs to be a certain structure to work well.


Spelling is critical (files and file would specify different variables).
Capital Letters are important (Image1 is not the same as image1)
Use comments to help you (and others) understand your code. Comments start a line with // and are in green. These are not executed in the code.
Each line ends with ;
ImageJ is open source (free) and people will help you if you have a question

Stack Overflow
Image.SC


Don‚Äôt post your own data unless necessary (Use ImageJ sample images)
    üîé File > Open Samples






Note



I clearly wrote this a few years ago‚Ä¶ ChatGPT is also a great place to get help.



Use the Macro Recorder to capture your actions as code.
  üîé Plugins > Macros > Record...
Test code on one image first.
Save the macro with the .ijm extension.

title: Writing Your First ImageJ Macro
text:
‚úèÔ∏è Let‚Äôs Create a Macro
Let‚Äôs write a macro, a small one first. Go to this folder and download the sample images.

Open FIJI
Drag and drop the sample Image ‚Äúsample-image1‚Äù into FIJI
üîé Plugins > Macros > Record‚Ä¶


A Record Window will pop-up

The record window is your best friend. It will record all the actions you take in FIJI and convert them into code. This is a great way to learn how to write macros, as you can see the code that corresponds to each action you take.

Click on the opened image
üîé Image > Stacks > Z Project‚Ä¶


run("Z Project...", "projection=[Max Intensity]");


üîé Image > Colour > Split Channels


run("Split Channels");


Click on Recorder Window. Click Create







Open a second Image (sample-image2)
Click Run. So quick!
Save the new macro. üîé File > Save As‚Ä¶ > max-projection_split-channels.ijm

‚úÖ Done!

section: ‚úèÔ∏è Let‚Äôs Create a Macro - A Bit More‚Ä¶

title: Writing Your First ImageJ Macro
text:
üî• Making a Macro Generic
This enables you to perform your macros, without having to specify the image name manually every time.
A reminder:

When writing code in the ImageJ language all lines must end with a semi-colon (;)
Code is case sensitive (Image1 is different to image1).

A lot of errors can be fixed by checking these two things.
Using the existing macro:

On the very first line add:


title = getTitle();

getTitle() is a built-in function that returns the name of the currently active image.
title is a variable ‚Äî it holds the result of the function.
The = sign assigns the value. Think of ‚Äòtitle‚Äô like a labeled box that now holds the image‚Äôs name. You can reuse this value later in your macro, for example, when saving results using the image name. Anywhere we have our image name ‚Äì we can change to title‚Ä¶
üí° Tip: You can name your variables anything (like imgName, filename, etc.), but title is a good descriptive choice here since we‚Äôre storing the image title.







Rules for Naming Variables











Rule
Example
Notes




1. Must start with a letter
cellCount
‚úÖ OK


2. Can contain letters, numbers, or underscores
image_01, threshold_level
‚úÖ OK


3. Cannot contain spaces
‚ùå cell count
Use underscores or camelCase instead


4. Cannot start with a number
‚ùå 1stImage
‚úÖ firstImage


5. Avoid symbols or punctuation
‚ùå title!, my-variable.



6. Case-sensitive
Title ‚â† title
Title and title are different


7. Avoid using built-in keywords or function names
‚ùå run, print, getTitle
These are reserved by ImageJ











Tips for Good Variable names










Tip
Why It Helps




‚úÖ Use descriptive names
e.g., nucleiCount, imageTitle


‚úÖ Use camelCase or snake_case for readability
e.g., cellArea, cell_area


‚úÖ Be consistent across your macro
Makes your code easier to read and maintain


‚ùå Avoid names like x, y, a unless for quick loops
Not informative






Now we need to change the image name in the selectImage() line.


selectImage(‚ÄúC3-MAX_‚Äù + title);

The + sign is used to concatenate (join) strings (words in ‚Äù ‚Äù and variables) together. The string ‚ÄúC3-MAX_‚Äù is joined with the value of the variable title that we assigned at the start of the macro.

Open sample-Image1. Press Run. Check output files. The macro should run with no errors. Repeat for sample-Image2. Check output files.

However‚Ä¶
Currently our results are being saved as ‚ÄúResults‚Äù and ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù, and these are being overwritten every time we run a new image. It is best to include the image name when saving the results, so that they are unique and do not get overwritten.

We can change:


saveAs("Results", "C:/Users/marni/ImageJ Macros/ImageJ Macro Tutorial/sample-images/Results.csv");

To:

selectWindow("Results");
saveAs("Results", "C:/Users/marni/ImageJ Macros/ImageJ Macro Tutorial/sample-images/" + "Results_" + title + ".csv");

Here we are selecting the Results Window, and saving it to the destination folder with the name Results_sample-image1.csv or Results_sample-image2.csv. The same can be done for the Summary file.

Change the Summary file name to:


selectWindow("Summary");
saveAs("Results", "C:/Users/marni/ImageJ Macros/ImageJ Macro Tutorial/sample-images/" + "Summary_" + title + ".csv");












Tip



Strings are pieces of text. In ImageJ, strings are enclosed in double quotes (‚Äú). For example,‚ÄùHello World‚Äù is a string. You can concatenate strings using the + operator.
Variables are like boxes that hold values. You can create a variable to store a string, number, or other data types. For example, myString = "Hello" creates a variable called myString that holds the string ‚ÄúHello‚Äù.
Variables do not need to be in quotes. Strings must be in quotes. A variable can be a string, but a string cannot be a variable. For example, myString = "Hello" is correct, but "myString" = "Hello" is incorrect.



Save the macro. Close all windows except the macro window. Drag and drop sample-image1 and sample-image2 into FIJI. Check the output files.












Fix the Mistake



Create a macro that stores a name in a variable and prints it. What is wrong with the following code? What is the error message?
"name" = "Mitochondria";
print(name);


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Macro Error:
Statement cannot begin with ‚Äò=‚Äô in line 1.
"name" = "Mitochondria";  // ‚ùå Invalid syntax
name = "Mitochondria";  // ‚úÖ Variable name is unquoted
print(name);  // ‚úÖ Prints the value of the variable
This error occurs because the macro is trying to assign a value to a string literal (the quoted text ‚Äúname‚Äù) instead of a variable. In ImageJ macros, variable names should not be enclosed in quotes.

Now try this code:
name = mitochondria
print(name)
What error message do you expect?


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Macro Error: Undefined variable in line 1.
This error occurs because the macro is trying to assign a variable (mitochondria - note it is not in quotes) to a variable name (name). Because we haven‚Äôt defined the variable mitochondria, the macro doesn‚Äôt know what it is. In ImageJ macros, variable names should be defined before they are used. To fix this, we can either define the variable mitochondria or use a string literal (e.g., ‚Äúmitochondria‚Äù) instead.









Fix the Mistake



Create a new macro with the following code:
title = "my image"
print(title);
What is wrong with the code? What is the error message?


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Macro Error: ‚Äò;‚Äô expected in line 1.
title = "my image"  // ‚ùå Missing semicolon
title = "my image";  // ‚úÖ Corrected code
print(title);  // ‚úÖ Prints the value of the variable
This error occurs because the macro is missing a semicolon at the end of the first line. In ImageJ macros, each statement must end with a semicolon.









Fix the Mistake



Create a new macro with the following code:
directory = getDirectory("Choose Directory";
print(directory);
What is wrong with the code? What is the error message?


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Macro Error: `‚Äò)‚Äô expected in line 1.
directory = getDirectory("Choose Directory";  // ‚ùå Missing closing parenthesis
directory = getDirectory("Choose Directory");  // ‚úÖ Corrected code
print(directory);  // ‚úÖ Prints the value of the variable
This error occurs because the macro is missing a closing parenthesis at the end of the first line. In ImageJ macros, each function call must have matching parentheses.









Fix the Mistake



Create a new macro with the following code:
threshold = 128;
threshold = "Low";
print(threshold);
What type of value does threshold hold?


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Initially, threshold holds a number (128)‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶but then it is overwritten with a string ‚ÄúLow‚Äù.
Result: the final print statement will output a string, not a number. This won‚Äôt crash the macro, but it can lead to unexpected behavior if you later try to use threshold as a number (e.g., in math operations).









Fix the Mistake



Try this macro code:
run = "Start";
print(run);
Will this code work? What colour will the text be?


üîç Show Answer and Explanation

Macro Error: ‚Äò(‚Äô expected in line 1.
run is a built-in function name in ImageJ macros ‚Äî using it as a variable name overwrites or shadows that function. You can tell its a function name because it is written in gold. Variables should be black. The macro is expecting the function run() and so is why the error message shows ‚Äò(‚Äô expected.
‚ùå Don‚Äôt use built-in function names like:

run
print
getTitle
showMessage

‚úÖ Instead, choose a different name:
run_status = "Start";
print(run_status);



Great, I now have my files saved in this filepath. I can now run this macro on any image I want, and it will save the results in the same file path with the image name included. This is a great start to automating analysis. But, what if I want to use this macro and save the results in a different folder each time it is run?

text:
üåà Bonus: Merging Channels
One very common task in image analysis is to merge channels together. This can be done using the Merge Channels command in FIJI. But we will use macros to automate this process. The code for merging channels is not as intuitive as the other commands we have seen so far. It requires a specific format. This is why I have decided to include it here as a bonus section.
Why Merge Channels? Merging channels allows you to:

Combine split grayscale images (C1, C2, C3‚Ä¶) into a single composite color image
Visualize multi-stain images with colors (e.g., red for BRN3A, green for ISLET1)
Export publication-ready RGB images

After processing or splitting channels individually, you‚Äôll often want to bring them back together for analysis or presentation.
So let‚Äôs start fresh with a new FIJI macro.

Open a new macro window in FIJI.
Open image sample-image1 in FIJI. This image of neurons has 4 channels. DAPI (nucleus), cell membrane stain, mitochondria stain and transmitted light. We should merge the Nucleus, cell membrane and mitochondria stain into one image.
Open up the macro recorder by going to


üîé Plugins > Macros > Record...


Then run split channels


üîé Image > Color > Split Channels


Now run the merge channels command


üîé Image > Color > Merge Channels...


In the merge channels dialog, select the channels you want to merge.


Select the first channel (e.g., C1) and choose a color (e.g., Blue)
Select the second channel (e.g., C2) and choose a color (e.g., Yellow)
Select the third channel (e.g., C3) and choose a color (e.g., Red)
Leave the fourth channel (e.g., C4) unselected as we want to leave out the transmitted light channel


üîé Image > Color > Merge Channels...


This will give:

run("Merge Channels...", "c1=C3-sample-image1.tif c3=C1-sample-image1.tif c7=C2-sample-image1.tif create");

What is happening here?

c1=‚Ä¶, c2=‚Ä¶, c3=‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ represent channel slots in the merge (Red = c1, Green = c2, Blue = c3, and so on). In reality, it doesn‚Äôt matter what color you choose, as long as you know which channel is which.
The filenames assigned to each slot (e.g., ‚ÄúC3-sample-image1.tif‚Äù) are the actual grayscale image windows open.
create means ‚Äúcreate a new composite image from these inputs.‚Äù

However, we want to keep our code generic, so that when we have another image this code will still work. We can use the getTitle() function to get the name of the image. This way, we can use the same macro for any image.

title = getTitle(); // Get the title of the current image
run("Split Channels");
run("Merge Channels...", "c1=[C1-" + title + "] c2=[C2-" + title + "] c3=[C3-" + title + "] create");

Take note of the capital letters and spaces. This is important in this case. Compare the recorder window output to this output.

Open sample-image3.tif and re-run the above code. You should see another image window open with the merged channels without the ransmitted light channel.

If you are sharing your code, you may want to add a license. A license tells other people:

‚úÖ What they can and can‚Äôt do with your code
‚úÖ Whether they can reuse it in their own projects
‚úÖ How they should give you credit

Some popular licenses include:

MIT License ‚Äì very open and permissive
GPL (General Public License) ‚Äì requires derived code to also be open
Creative Commons (e.g.¬†CC-BY) ‚Äì common for educational material and data


üß≠ You can explore license types at choosealicense.com

üìÑ Sharing Your Code
The best way to share code is to use a version control system like Git. This allows you to keep track of changes, collaborate with others, and share your code easily.
GitHub is a popular platform that lets you store and publish your code online.
You can upload your macro scripts, images, and tutorials so others can use and contribute to them.
Here‚Äôs how to get started:

Create a free account at github.com
Click ‚ÄúNew repository‚Äù and give your project a name
Add your .ijm files, documentation, and a LICENSE file
Write a README.md to explain what your macro does
(Optional) Use Git to push updates from your local computer


üß≠ Learn more at: https://docs.github.com/en/get-started

üí° GitHub makes it easier for others to find your code, give feedback, and cite your work!

title: Writing Your First ImageJ Macro
text:
üõ†Ô∏è Troubleshooting
Writing macros is a learning process, and errors are very normal! When something goes wrong, ImageJ usually gives you an error message that helps you figure out what‚Äôs wrong.

Spelling ‚Äî Make sure all function names (like run, Dialog.create) and variable names are spelled correctly.
Brackets ‚Äî Check that every opening (, {, or [ has a matching closing one.
Capitalization ‚Äî Dialog.getString() is not the same as dialog.getstring() ‚Äî ImageJ is case-sensitive!
Semicolons ‚Äî Most lines must end with a ;. Forgetting one is one of the most common causes of errors.
Quotes for Strings ‚Äî Strings must be wrapped in double quotes: "Hello" not Hello.
Line Numbers in Errors ‚Äî The error message usually tells you what line it occurred on, but it‚Äôs not always exact ‚Äî check the lines just above and below too.
Start small ‚Äî If you‚Äôre stuck, comment out sections of your macro and run it in smaller chunks.
Use print() for debugging ‚Äî You can print variables to the log to see what values are being stored.
use wait() to slow down the macro if it is running too fast. This can help you see what is happening at each step. Is useful for debugging and for running your analysis.
If you don‚Äôt know where to start, or how to write a piece of code, start by using the macro recorder. The macro recorder will record your actions in FIJI and give you a starting point.
Before running on a full dataset, make sure the macro works on a single image.
If your macro is running slowly, restart FIJI or your computer to clear memory. Often macros run faster when you have less open, so if you have images building up that do not close, add lines of code that close the image before looping to the next image.







Note



I find my macros run much faster if I do not have Google chrome open, chrome eats up so much of your RAM‚Ä¶

üì¶ A note about .lif files
If you have .lif files, these need to be converted to individual .tif images prior to batch processing.
If you are using .lif files, you can use the Lif-to-Tif macro to convert them to .tif files. This macro will open the .lif file and save each image in the file as a separate .tif file. This macro was created by Alexandre Hego: alexandre.hego@uliege.be. It works really well for .lif project files, including .lif files with tilescans. I have added this macro to my GitHub page for accessibility Lif-to-Tif.

üîó Explore My Macro Collection
If you are looking for inspiration, or want to see some examples of macros I have made, check out my GitHub page. These get updated regularly. Try running them yourself with the provided sample images in each repository to see how they work. Make sure to read the README file before starting! Feel free to use these macros for analysing your own images if applicable. However, please cite the work if you do so. Refer to the license file in each repository for more information.
If you come across any issues, or want some features added to the macros, please let me know. Requests can be made through GitHub by going to the repository and clicking on the issues tab. Here you can submit a request for a new feature, or report a bug.
Currently available macros include:

Lif-to-Tif
Double-Positive-Nuclei
Double-Positive-Nuclei-With-Checks
Double-Triple-Positive-Nuclei-With-Checks
Neuron_Confluence
More to come!
